Claim: Media report shows BJP has tampered with EVM machines. The collector and SP of Bhind, Madhya Pradesh, have been removed after it was found that the VVPAT machine was dispensing slips with only BJP symbols.
Explanation: This is a five-year-old incident and has no connection to any recent or upcoming election. The Bhind Collector and SP were shunted out in April 2017, ahead of by-election to Ater assembly seat in the district.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Picture shows the man who led the coup in Africa’s Burkina Faso.
Explanation: On January 24, Burkina Faso’s military regime announced on state television that it had seized power. However, the image in question is of the captain who read out the statement on behalf of Lt-Col Paul-Henri Damiba, the coup leader.
Label: Half True

Claim: Video shows a daring mid-air photoshoot of an airshow by the Indian Air Force on Republic Day.
Explanation: This video is from the rehearsal of an airshow by the Royal Saudi Air Force as part of the Kingdom's 90th National Day in 2020.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Former TMC MLA from Bengal’s Purulia district, Purna Chandra Bauri, unfurled the party flag in place of Tricolour to celebrate Republic Day.
Explanation: This video does not show the complete event. On Republic Day, Bauri did hoist the TMC flag, but before that, he had also unfurled the national flag on another pole beside the party flag.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Heart-rending pictures of police brutality during the ongoing protests against RRB NTPC exam results.
Explanation: These images are old and of different incidents that have taken place in different states. However, there has been massive uproar against the police crackdown on RRB protesters.
Label: Half True

Claim: Pictures show police in Bihar brutally attacking candidates protesting against the RRB NTPC exam results.
Explanation: These images are from a 2018 protest held in Lucknow against alleged disparities in the recruitment of assistant teachers in UP. However, there has also been outrage over police highhandedness against RRB protesters.
Label: Half True

Claim: This image of an envelope with the ‘cycle’ symbol containing Rs 500 is proof that Samajwadi Party leader from Meerut Atul Pradhan is distributing money to lure voters.
Explanation: This image is manipulated and Atul Pradhan’s name has been added to it. The original image is old and has been present on the Internet since at least 2017.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Video shows an Indian soldier in a helicopter rescuing a bird tangled in power lines.
Explanation: This is a 2013 video from Virginia Beach, United States. It shows crew of an energy company rescuing a seagull that was trapped in power lines for hours.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: AAP leaders observe Muslim rituals during elections in Delhi and wear saffron scarves during polls in UP.
Explanation: None of the two images of AAP leaders wearing skull caps was taken during any election in Delhi. Both these images were taken in July 2016. Assembly and municipal elections in Delhi were held in 2015 and 2017.
Label: Half True

Claim: Image of man rescuing a baby after the deadly airstrike on Yemen.
Explanation: An airstrike by the Saudi-led coalition on Yemen’s Saada on January 21 killed over 80 people, including children. However, the above picture was taken in April 2016 after airstrikes on a medical centre in Aleppo, Syria.
Label: Half True

Claim: AAP chief Arvind Kejriwal has praised Bhagwant Mann, his party’s CM candidate for Punjab, for his decision to quit drinking from January 1, 2022.
Explanation: This video is from an AAP rally that was held ahead of Lok Sabha elections in 2019.
Label: Half True

Claim: Video shows IAS officer Vijay Singh lashing out at Western countries at an international forum for their colonial attitude towards India when it comes to action on climate change.
Explanation: The man in the video is Vijay Prashad, a historian and journalist. He was speaking at the COP26 summit in Glasgow last year.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Bodies of children being retrieved from the debris following an airstrike in Yemen’s Saada on January 21.
Explanation: None of these images are from the site of the deadly attack that killed over 80 people, including children. These images are from conflicts in different countries of the Middle East and have been in circulation for several years.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Video of protesters blocking Union minister Smriti Irani’s convoy in the run-up to elections in Uttar Pradesh.
Explanation: This is an old video from 2020. A group of Congress workers had blocked Irani’s cavalcade in Varanasi in protest against the alleged gang rape and murder of a 19-year-old woman in UP’s Hathras.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Video shows a man falling to his death from a high-rise building while trying to escape from a fire break out in Mumbai’s Tardeo area on January 22, 2022.
Explanation: This video is from a fire incident that took place in Mumbai's Currey Road on October 22, 2021. However, a major fire did break out in a building in Mumbai’s Tardeo area on January 22.
Label: Half True

Claim: Video shows the collision of an under-maintenance Indian satellite with the International Space Station. American astronaut Michael Collins died during the incident.
Explanation: This is a 3D animation video created by CGI artist Aleksey Patrev. American astronaut Michael Collins of Apollo 11 fame died of cancer at the age of 90 in April 2021.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: In a recent speech in Goa, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has warned the Congress against its corrupt practices.
Explanation: This speech is over five years old. It was made on November 13, 2016, just a few days after demonetisation. In this emotional speech, PM Modi had warned of stringent action against those indulging in corrupt practices, and also appealed to people to support the fight against corruption.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: People filming tsunami waves in Tonga risking their lives.
Explanation: A volcanic eruption in the South Pacific triggered a massive tsunami in the tiny island nation of Tonga a few days back, killing three people and wreaking havoc. But the above video is of a tidal bore in Indonesia shot in December 2021.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: A 4,000-year-old wooden chariot was found near Sanauli, UP, whose wheels are covered with thick copper plates. Copper helmets, comb and a mirror decorated with camel and peacock were also found.
Explanation: Although there have been remarkable discoveries in Sanauli in recent years, the chariot seen in the viral post was unearthed in China’s Henan province. Reports said these are “3000-year-old remains of horses and wooden chariots from a Zhou Dynasty tomb in Luoyang”.
Label: Half True

Claim: Image shows construction of the world’s longest pipeline project from Kandla in Gujarat to Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh.
Explanation: Though such a project is in the works, the image used was taken in Germany in April 2010. This pipeline was constructed for supplying natural gas from Russia to Western Europe.
Label: Half True

Claim: Picture of Arvind Kejriwal and his party MP Bhagwant Mann sitting in front of liquor shops.
Explanation: The viral image is morphed. In the original picture, Kejriwal and Mann are seen sitting on a cot amid mustard fields. This was during their interaction with farmers in Punjab’s Chamkaur Sahib a few days back.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: These images are of a Naxal-provoked IED blast that injured three SSB jawans on January 14, 2022 in Chhattisgarh.
Explanation: While it is true that three jawans were injured in an IED blast in Chhattisgarh on January 14, none of these images are from the incident. These images are from different Naxal attacks that took place in India between 2013 and 2021.
Label: Half True

Claim: British man discovers ancient Roman coins that were underground for 1,700 years in his first-ever treasure hunt.
Explanation: The incident happened nearly 12 years ago and the viral post is copied from a news report dated September 9, 2009.
Label: Half True

Claim: Mandating the use of masks among citizens is a war crime according to the Nuremberg Code.
Explanation: This is a 2018 incident from Baghpat, Uttar Pradesh. It shows three students and a teacher beating a man with sticks after he harassed them in their college. The video has no connection with the Congress campaign in poll-bound UP.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Inspired by Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi’s new campaign, 'Ladki Hoon, Lad Sakti Hoon', girls thrashed a man who was misbehaving with them.
Explanation: This is a 2018 incident from Baghpat, Uttar Pradesh. It shows three students and a teacher beating a man with sticks after he harassed them in their college. The video has no connection with the Congress campaign in poll-bound UP.
Label: Half True

Claim: An image shows the Brahmin community in Uttar Pradesh burning BJP flags and declaring not to vote for the party.
Explanation: This image was taken in Rajasthan in 2018. Supporters of a local politician named Hansraj Patel were burning BJP flags after the party denied him a ticket for the state assembly elections at the time.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Tribute to Rakesh Sharma, the first Indian astronaut to walk on the moon, on his birthday on January 13.
Explanation: No astronaut from India has landed on the moon till now. Rakesh Sharma was the first Indian to travel to space. In 1984, Sharma, along with Russian cosmonauts, spent a week in space laboratory Salyut-7.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Video shows production of artificial sugar from thermocol.
Explanation: Conclusion - Experts have clarified that the video shows recycling of thermocol into synthetic resins for reuse. The plastic granules are then used for production of different plastic products such as chairs, tables, toys, decorative items, etc.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: In an amazing archaeological finding, a Civil War-era steam locomotive has been unearthed in pristine condition in Atlanta, United States.
Explanation: The 19th century locomotive's name is "Texas". It was kept in Atlanta's Civil War Museum for years. In 2015, it was relocated to the Atlanta History Center where the above pictures were taken. It is not an archaeological finding.
Label: Half True

Claim: This video shows a glimpse of the Cabinet Committee on Security meeting where removal of all Sikhs from the army was being discussed.
Explanation: This video is doctored. The actual video shows the Cabinet Committee on Security meeting that was held on December 8, 2021, after CDS General Bipin Rawat’s death in a chopper crash. The audio was taken from a discussion that happened on Clubhouse social audio app.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Video shows “Khalistan Zindabad” slogans being raised during Modi’s visit to Punjab on January 5. The PM’s convoy was stopped due to protests some distance away from his scheduled public meeting in Ferozepur.
Explanation: The video is old and not related to PM Modi’s recent visit to Punjab.
Label: Half True

Claim: Image shows a large crowd that had gathered for Modi’s public meeting in Punjab’s Ferozepur on January 5. The event was later cancelled due to the security breach of the PM’s convoy.
Explanation: This image is from a public meeting held by Yogi Adityanath in Deoband, Uttar Pradesh, on January 4.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: A photo comparison of upgraded gear used by the CRPF in 2011 and 2022.
Explanation: The claim is misleading as the image shared as that of the CRPF jawan from 2011 was clicked in 2017, while the second image is of an elite commando of the paramilitary force.
Label: Half True

Claim: Tejas Express from Mumbai to Goa, illuminated for Christmas.
Explanation: This video shows the “Christmas Train of Lights”, a festival train run during Christmas in South West England.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Pope Francis cancels the Bible and proposes to create a new book.
Explanation: This news report screenshot is from a 2018 article published by a satire site. There is no credible news report about Pope Francis making such a statement.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: In 1780, Queen Velu Nachiyar of Tamil Nadu's Sivaganga became the first Indian ruler to fight the British.
Explanation: The English East Indian Company fought several Indian rulers before 1780, including some iconic episodes of Anglo-Indian history like the Battle of Plassey (1757), the Battle of Buxar (1764) and the First Anglo-Mysore War (1767–69).
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: This asteroid - caught on camera in the skies over India - just missed hitting earth in December.
Explanation: It is true that three asteroids went past earth between November 29 to December 17 this year, but the viral image is that of a meteorite photographed six years ago. Photographer Prasenjeet Yadav was taking pictures in the Western Ghats in 2015 when his camera accidentally caught a green streak of light across the night sky.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: The Shiv Sena government in Maharashtra has changed the name of Mumbai’s iconic Veer Mata Jijabai Bhosale Udyan to Hajrat Haji Peer Baba Rani Baug.
Explanation: The public garden is named after Chhatrapati Shivaji’s mother and there has been no change in its name. The stone plaque seen in the image is of a dargah that has existed in the zoo premises for decades.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Prime Minister Narendra Modi was booed by the people of Varanasi during his recent trip which the media never showed. People shouted anti-Modi slogans while he was walking down the streets with Yogi Adityanath.
Explanation: The viral video is edited. The audio “Hai Hai Modi” has been superimposed on the video. In the original video, people were actually heard raising pro-Modi slogans and trying to take a selfie with him.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Bill Gates had created a video game called “Omicron” in 1999. The game was about demons pretending to be humans and harvesting their souls. Is it mere coincidence that the same variant is ravaging humankind in 2021?
Explanation: This is yet another conspiracy theory. The actual name of the video game was “Omikron: The Nomad Soul”. It was created by a French video game developer and not by Gates or Microsoft.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Theme marriage gone horribly wrong in Gwalior. A bride married a different groom after she mistakenly landed at a different venue during her paragliding entry.
Explanation: This is a fictitious story published by satire website “The Fauxy”. The website in its disclaimer section has clearly advised readers not to confuse its articles as genuine.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Picture shows Niagara Falls in Canada lit up in honour of Bangladesh Victory Day.
Explanation: Niagara Falls in Canada was illuminated in green and red for Christmas. Bangladesh Victory Day is marked on December 16. The calendar for Niagara’s illumination schedule does not even mention Bangladesh Victory Day on its website.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Kolkata-based Neena Gupta becomes first Indian to win the Ramanujan Prize for young mathematicians.
Explanation: The claim is misleading as Neena Gupta is the fourth Indian to win the award. Ritabrata Munshi (2018), Amalendu Krishna (2015) and Sujatha Ramdorai (2006) from India have won the prize before.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Images show actor Kangana Ranaut celebrating the Vijay Diwas with BSF jawans this year.
Explanation: These images are from Kangana’s visit to the BSF Frontier Headquarter in Jammu on February 7, 2017, to promote her film ‘Rangoon’.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Scientists at Pfizer have warned that weekly vaccinations are required to prevent an Omicron-induced lockdown.
Explanation: The article was originally published on a satire website. However, some people believed it to be a genuine news report.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: The discovery of this strange looking mummy only strengthens the belief that aliens visited ancient Egypt. Scientists cannot explain anything about this mummy which was uncovered by Dr Victor Lubeck, a retired professor from the University of Pennsylvania.
Explanation: These are two mummified baby girls found by Egyptologist Howard Carter while discovering King Tutankhamun’s tomb in 1922. DNA tests suggest that Tutankhamun was most likely the father of the two fetuses.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: This is an emotional story about an Army veteran who lost his son in an IAF chopper crash. The man had already lost two other sons in different wars. Netizens assume the son to be a victim of the Coonoor chopper crash that claimed the lives of CDS Bipin Rawat and 12 others.
Explanation: This message has been in circulation on the internet at least since 2013 and is not related to the Coonoor chopper crash.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: These are pictures of vehicle graveyards in Japan.
Explanation: These are pictures of vehicle graveyards in the US. One of them is a digital recreation of a vehicle graveyard in New Mexico by Turkish artist Ayd?n Büyükta?. The other two were taken by Reuters photographer Lucy Nicholson in California in 2018.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: This is the satellite video of the helicopter crash that killed CDS Bipin Rawat. It appears that the tail rotor got snapped and the chopper turned in the reverse direction, leading to the crash.
Explanation: This is an animation created by a Tamil news channel. The channel never claimed it to be satellite imagery. The video just tried to explain how the crash took place. The incident is being probed by a tri-service commission.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Video shows an angry mob resorting to arson in Nagaland’s Tuensang after the killing of civilians by security forces.
Explanation: This video is of a fire that had broken out in Tuensang on December 5 due to short circuit. A few shops were damaged in the blaze. The video is not related to the protests that broke out following the killing of civilians by security forces.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: While campaigning in Uttar Pradesh, Priyanka Gandhi has warned that if namaaz on roads are prohibited, the Congress will disallow yoga in parks.
Explanation: So far, there is no credible report about Priyanka making such a statement during her election campaign in UP. Also, the statement has been in circulation since 2018 and was earlier attributed to only “Congress”.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: On November 7, 1966, hundreds of sadhus and gau rakshaks, who were part of the anti-cow slaughter agitation, were killed in police firing in Delhi at the behest of the Indira Gandhi government.
Explanation: The incident took place when the agitators’ Parliament march turned violent. Historical documents, including Parliament records and newspaper articles, show eight deaths, including seven agitators and a policeman.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: This is the poster of a movie named “The Omicron Variant” which was released in 1963.
Explanation: This is an edited poster that was created using the poster of a 1974 film “Phase IV”. The title “The Omicron Variant” has been added to it. There is no actual movie with this name.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: The new Omicron variant of coronavirus is deadlier, with higher death rates and often no symptoms. RTPCR tests cannot detect the strain.
Explanation: WHO has assessed Omicron’s risk levels to be “very high”. However, as per latest reports, it is still uncertain about the transmissibility and severity of the strain. No death due to Omicron has been reported yet and RTPCR tests are still recommended to detect coronavirus.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: This dilapidated structure with the roof missing is a government school in Gujarat.
Explanation: The picture is almost four years old and of a government school in Uttarakhand’s Almora district. The school is in the same condition now.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Amit Shah is reading the blank reverse side of the Preamble.
Explanation: This picture was taken during Constitution Day celebrations in Parliament on November 26. The President was reading out the Preamble and other members repeated it after him. The Preamble leaflet has two sides with the text in English and Hindi respectively. Members were reading the Preamble in Hindi.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: UPTET aspirants spent the whole night like this in harsh winters and then came to know in the morning that the exam was cancelled.
Explanation: This picture is from outside the Congress office in Lucknow where several unemployed youths from Rajasthan had come to meet Priyanka Gandhi on November 27. Failing to do so, they spent the night outside in protest.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: A man publicly puts pie on the face of an airline CEO who mandated the Covid vaccine for all his employees.
Explanation: This is a 2017 video from Australia and is unrelated to the pandemic or Covid vaccines. The man puts pie into the face of an airline CEO because the latter supports same-sex marriage.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Vandalism has begun after the withdrawal of farm laws was announced.
Explanation: The video was shot in Karnal, Haryana on January 10, 2021, when Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar was to attend a Kisan Mahapanchayat. But he had to cancel the programme as agitating farmers flung chairs, tore banners and vandalised the venue demanding scrapping of the farm laws. This is not a recent video.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: This is how the Noida international airport would look like upon completion.
Explanation: This is the Beijing Daxing International Airport in China. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on November 25 laid the foundation stone of the Noida international airport at Jewar.
Label: Half True

Claim: New Zealand cricketers were greeted with saffron scarves upon their arrival in Kanpur for the first Test.
Explanation: The viral picture is from October 2017 when the Black Caps reached Kanpur to play the third ODI of a bilateral series. Saffron scarves were kept at the entrance of their hotel this time too, but were not used to greet the players.
Label: Half True

Claim: Video shows people in Austria protesting against the renewed lockdown.
Explanation: Though Austria is witnessing protests against renewed lockdown, this picture shows supporters of German football team Borussia Mönchengladbach marching down a street in Austria’s Graz in 2019.
Label: Half True

Claim: Lenticular clouds over Mount Fuji in Japan.
Explanation: This is a photoshopped picture. The actual image was taken by one Raymond R Carr in 2005. In the actual image, only one layer of lenticular cloud can be seen. The other layers have been digitally added in the viral image.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: On his birth anniversary, this picture of Tipu Sultan reminds us of his valiance against British colonialism.
Explanation: The viral picture is morphed. The original picture is of Chhatrapati Shivaji with his horse. The Shivaji poster has been up for sale on several e-commerce websites for long.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Haryana Roadways buses will now be painted in red! Here’s the new look.
Explanation: Haryana Roadways has no plans of changing the colour of its white-and-blue buses. It already has some red Volvos in its fleet for deluxe services.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Photos show the site of the Manipur ambush by militants that killed Colonel Viplav Tripathi, his family, and four other soldiers.
Explanation: While the first photo is from a 2015 militant attack in Manipur, the second image is from a territorial fight between villagers straddling the states of Assam and Nagaland.
Label: Half True

Claim: This is a screenshot of actor-comedian Vir Das’s Wikipedia page which shows that his real name is Vir Abdullah Das.
Explanation: The screenshot is of his edited Wikipedia page. His actual name is Vir Das and he is a Hindu.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Video of a fight between a woman and the flight crew over the former refusing to sit beside her unvaccinated co-passenger.
Explanation: The video does not show a real incident. It is a short film titled “Covid Flight”.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: This is what sunset on Earth looks like from space.
Explanation: This image is a still taken from a computer-generated stock video that shows sunrise from space. The video was created by a German artist. Even NASA has denied that they’ve released the image.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: After Pakistan’s defeat to Australia in the ICC T20 World Cup semifinal, stones were thrown at the house of Pak cricketer Hasan Ali for dropping a catch that allowed Matthew Wade to ensure Australia’s thrilling victory.
Explanation: Sources from Hasan’s family and local journalists from Pakistan confirmed to AFWA that the claim is false. The photo of the house with the broken window glass is from an October 2021 incident in Karnataka.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: An Australian fan chanting 'Bharat Maata ki Jai' and 'Vande Mataram' after Australia defeated Pakistan by five wickets in the T20 World Cup at Dubai.
Explanation: This video is from the January 2021 edition of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy, a Test cricket series played between India and Australia. The series was held at the Gabba stadium in Brisbane.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said his daughter can never marry a person who does not have the ability to create wealth.
Explanation: Musk has not given such a statement. Financial quotes borrowed from various videos and articles have been stitched together and falsely attributed to him. Also, Musk does not have a daughter.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Former Australian cricketer Ricky Ponting has taken a dig at India’s early exit from the T20 World Cup, saying money cannot buy success and Pakistan has proved that.
Explanation: It is a cooked-up statement. Ponting has made no such remarks.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Image of BOSS, the largest structure in the universe discovered so far.
Explanation: This is a computer-generated artwork that shows the distribution of galaxies in the universe.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Video of celebrations inside aircraft before Tata Air India’s first flight took off from India to Canada.
Explanation: This video is from 2018 when Air India resumed flights between Birmingham, United Kingdom, and Amritsar after eight years.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Video shows garbage floating around a waterlogged market in Chennai after heavy rainfall.
Explanation: Though several parts of Tamil Nadu, including Chennai, have been affected with intense rainfall and waterlogging, this particular video is from Sadar Bazaar in New Delhi when the Capital witnessed heavy downpour a couple of months back.
Label: Half True

Claim: This video shows the Indian cricket captain Virat Kohli asking his Afghan counterpart Mohammad Nabi to choose bowling after the latter won the toss in the match held on November 3 between the two countries in the T20 World Cup 2021. This is evidence of match-fixing between India and Afghanistan.
Explanation: In the video, after winning the toss, Nabi says, “We will bowl first”, not Kohli. According to the T20 World Cup playing conditions, the captain of the side winning the toss shall decide whether to bat or to field and notify the opposing captain and the umpires of his decision.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Picture shows a 17-year-old youth from Uttar Pradesh smashing his TV after India's defeat to New Zealand in the T20 World Cup.
Explanation: The picture is from 2017 when India lost to Pakistan in the Champions Trophy final and some TV sets were smashed on the streets of Ahmedabad.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: One should never take a shower while the geyser is on. This can lead to the person getting electrocuted.
Explanation: Though such incidents have been reported, they are rare and occur only when the earthing or geyser parts are faulty. However, geysers these days are equipped with advanced safety features.
Label: Half True

Claim: India has never beaten New Zealand in ICC events.
Explanation: India has played three T20 World Cup matches against New Zealand and lost all of them. But in the 50-over format, India has won three of the eight matches against New Zealand – two in 1987 and one in the 2003 World Cup.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Shiv Sena chief Uddhav Thackeray has insulted Marathi icon Chhatrapati Shivaji by putting a wooden plank on his portrait to accommodate Indira Gandhi’s picture.
Explanation: The picture was clicked on October 31 at Uddhav’s residence-cum-office. Indira Gandhi’s photograph was kept on a wooden stand away from the wall and it wasn’t covering Shivaji’s portrait either. The angle of the picture has confused netizens.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: After Kannada superstar Puneeth Rajkumar’s death, Dr Devi Shetty said he died because of “doing too much to be fit”. Everything should be done in moderation, Dr Shetty advised.
Explanation: The viral statement has been wrongly attributed to Dr Shetty. His office has called the message “fake”.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Prime Minister Narendra Modi humiliated in Italy, had to take a taxi for his trips.
Explanation: The picture is morphed. The original image tweeted by ANI does not have the ‘taxi’ logo on PM Modi’s vehicle. The picture was captured on October 30 while the PM was leaving Vatican City after meeting Pope Francis.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: A team of six NCB officials led by Sameer Wankhede was recently attacked by a mob of 60 people in Goregaon, Mumbai.
Explanation: The incident took place last year. No such incident has occurred in Goregaon recently.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Punjab CM Charanjit Singh Channi climbed a pole and fixed the power supply of Kurali area after getting complaints that electricity was disconnected in poor households due to non-payment of bills.
Explanation: The incident is from 2016, before Channi became the Punjab CM. Channi had climbed a pole to reconnect the power supply to the waterworks at Rupnagar's Sihon Majra village. The power supply of the waterworks was allegedly disconnected due to non-payment of electricity bills.
Label: Half True

Claim: Union Home minister Amit Shah has renamed Andaman and Nicobar Islands as Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose Islands.
Explanation: Shah did not rename the Union territory after Netaji. However, in 2018, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had renamed Ross Island, one of the islands in the archipelago, as Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose Island.
Label: Half True

Claim: This is what Mark Zuckerberg said after the six-hour global outage of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp. The downtime was planned because they wanted to enter the cryptocurrency business.
Explanation: This is part of Zuckerberg’s speech at Georgetown University, United States, in October 2019. He was speaking about freedom of expression on social media. Facebook has blamed faulty configuration behind the recent outage. The viral clip is edited and a graphics on cryptocurrency overlaid on it.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: According to Reuters, a 13-year-old Chinese hacker named Sun Jisu is behind the recent Facebook outage.
Explanation: Neither Reuters nor any other credible media outlet has claimed that Facebook was hacked. The social networking platform has said a faulty configuration led to the outage.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Pilibhit Lok Sabha MP Varun Gandhi has removed “BJP” from his Twitter bio. This indicates that he may leave the BJP soon.
Explanation: Varun Gandhi’s Twitter bio did not have the word “BJP” for the last seven years. The last time it was seen was way back in October 2014.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Norway has reclassified Covid-19, saying it’s no more dangerous than common flu.
Explanation: With dip in cases, Norway has lifted Covid restrictions in the country. But it has not reclassified the disease or said that it is “no more dangerous than ordinary flu”. The claim is a distortion of a comment given by a health official to a local tabloid.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Yohani De Silva, the Sri Lankan singer who has won the hearts of Indians with her song “Manike Mage Hithe”, has been appointed the cultural ambassador between the two countries by the Indian High Commission in Colombo.
Explanation: The Indian High Commission in Sri Lanka had praised Yohani for the song and termed her the “newest cultural ambassador”. But it was misinterpreted by netizens. It was only a praise and there has been no official appointment.
Label: Half True

Claim: Rakesh Tikait has openly threatened media houses saying they are the next targets. The farmers’ leader has asked media to either support the agitation or face consequences.
Explanation: The video is edited. In the longer version of the video, Tikait is heard referring to the Centre’s policies towards farmers. He said the government’s next target could be media houses and called upon them to join the protests.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Subramanian Swamy spotted at a press briefing of the Opposition parties and has officially joined them.
Explanation: The man in the image is Congress leader Manish Chatrath, who is currently the AICC in-charge of Arunachal Pradesh and Meghalaya.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: These graves in Japan are equipped with QR codes, scanning which one can get information about the deceased’s life.
Explanation: This is a theme park in Southwest China. Visitors can scan the QR codes to commemorate victims of the Nanjing Massacre and Bombing of Chongqing, both committed by Japanese troops in China during World War II.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Former UP CM Akhilesh Yadav has said through a tweet that BJP may have taken the "Bahu" of SP, but it will not be able to defeat SP.
Explanation: The viral tweet in the name of Akhilesh Yadav was made in a fake manner. Akhilesh has not given any such statement about Aparna Yadav.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Hot coconut water can kill cancer cells: Tata Memorial Hospital Message from Rajendra Badway.
Explanation: Tata Memorial Hospital Director Dr. Hospital officials said Rajendra Badway had not given such a message. Moreover, it has no scientific basis. Experts also warn cancer patients to drink only soft drinks as prescribed by a doctor.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: This email was sent to an employee by his boss. It states that it is mandatory to wear a mask during the zoom meeting of the office.
Explanation: This is a fictitious email posted as a satire by a TikTok user. Later some people took it for real.
Label: Absolutely false

Claim: Former UP CM Akhilesh Yadav worshiped Lord Parshuram wearing shoes in Lucknow.
Explanation: Akhilesh did not wear shoes while worshiping Lord Parashuram. The black thing seen in Akhilesh's feet in the picture are socks.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: Actor and social worker Sonu Sood has joined the Congress party.
Explanation: Sonu Sood's sister Malvika Sood has joined the Congress and not himself.
Label: Mostly lies

Claim: It can be seen in the video how an airplane carrying passengers in Indonesia narrowly escaped from the crash.
Explanation: This is not a video of a real plane crash. It is made with the help of computer software.
Label: Absolutely false
